figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Screenshot of a preprint record display in PMC (PMC8282109). This example record includes green information panel identifying the record as a preprint that has not been peer reviewed, the preprint indicator in the citation, and the yellow related content information panel that points to the associated peer-reviewed journal version and preprint server.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Screenshot of a preprint record display in PubMed (PMID: 34268520). This example record includes green information panel identifying the record as a preprint that has not been peer reviewed, the preprint indicator in the citation metadata, and Cite tool pop-up window with the “[Preprint]” indicator.

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: Screenshot of a preprint record search result in PubMed. This example includes the preprint indicator following the DOI as well as the Updated identifier, indicating that a peer-reviewed journal version is available.

figure_4.title: Figure 4.
figure_4.caption: Screenshot of search results that include preprint records in PMC. These examples include the “Preprint” indicator following the preprint server name and display of the “Published in” link for any associated peer-reviewed journal version.

figure_5.title: Figure 5.
figure_5.caption: Breakdown of preprints by server during the first two years of the Pilot (see Supplemental File 3).

figure_6.title: Figure 6.
figure_6.caption: Number of preprints added to PMC upon launch (June 9, 2020) of the NIH Preprint Pilot and in each subsequent quarter of the pilot during the first 2 years (see Supplemental File 3).

figure_7.title: Figure 7.
figure_7.caption: Bar graph showing number of preprints added to the Pilot at the time of launch and in each subsequent quarter of Phase 1, by license type.

figure_9.title: Figure 9.
figure_9.caption: Quarterly breakdown of preprint status as of December 2022 based on date preprint was posted.

figure_10.title: Figure 10.
figure_10.caption: Number of respondents to the preprint survey by user group.

figure_11.title: Figure 11.
figure_11.caption: Survey respondents and their responses to whether they had previously heard of preprints in a survey of PubMed and PMC users in July and August 2021.

figure_12.title: Figure 12.
figure_12.caption: Users’ responses on whether it was clear to users that they were viewing a preprint, by audience type.

figure_13.title: Figure 13.
figure_13.caption: Survey responses on the importance of preprint discovery (i.e., “How important is it to be able to discover and access preprints?”)

figure_14.title: Figure 14.
figure_14.caption: Responses to, “To what extent does having preprints in PubMed or PubMed Central increase or decrease your trust in the information found in PubMed or PubMed Central?”

claims.sentence: The text in this panel notes that the article has not been peer reviewed and includes a link to more information about the “NIH Preprint Pilot.” To communicate the “NIH-supported” scope of the pilot, an NIH-branded preprint banner was also added to records in PMC (Figure 1).

This example record includes green information panel identifying the record as a preprint that has not been peer reviewed, the preprint indicator in the citation, and the yellow related content information panel that points to the associated peer-reviewed journal version and preprint server.A “Preprint” indicator was also added to the displayed citation metadata and “Cite” tool in PMC and PubMed to foster transparency as well as accurate citation (Figure 2).

This example record includes green information panel identifying the record as a preprint that has not been peer reviewed, the preprint indicator in the citation metadata, and Cite tool pop-up window with the “[Preprint]” indicator.Additionally, the yellow information panel in PMC that displays prior to the abstract and includes related content links was expanded to include a pointer to the preprint on the source preprint server website and a link from the preprint record to an associated peer-reviewed journal version, when available (Figure 1).

Users may also access and view the preprint record directly from the source preprint server by clicking on the server link in this panel, the hyperlinked DOI in PMC and PubMed, or the server-branded “LinkOut” button in PubMed (Figure 2).
Preprints that were linked to published journal articles were labeled as “Updated” in PubMed (Figure 3).
In PMC, a “Published in” link was added to the search results display to take the user directly to the peer-reviewed journal version, if available (Figure 4).
This example includes the preprint indicator following the DOI as well as the Updated identifier, indicating that a peer-reviewed journal version is available.Figure 4.
Of the preprint records added to PMC and PubMed, the majority were posted to either medRxiv (47%) or bioRxiv (38%) (Figure 5).
The volume of preprints identified as in scope for Phase 1 varied over time, peaking at 538 preprints in the first quarter of the pilot (June 9 – September 9, 2020; see Figure 6).
Since June 2020, there was quarterly growth in the number of NIH-supported authors selecting some type of Creative Commons license (see Figure 7).

Of the 2,767 preprint records available in PubMed at the end of October 2021, there were only 20 that were returned in search results that were not viewed.Accelerated discovery
Approximately 72% of or 2,512 preprints added to PMC and PubMed through June 2022 had been linked to a peer-reviewed journal version by December 2022 (Figure 9).
Survey respondents represented a cross-section of PMC and PubMed user groups, with one-third of respondents being researchers (Figure 10).

Sixty-two percent of survey respondents (201) reported having previously heard of preprints, although there was variability across user types (see also Figure 11):
Figure 11.

Survey responses indicated that users were generally able to distinguish that they were viewing a preprint record in PMC and PubMed; Seventy percent (177) indicated that it was “Clear,” noting differences across user types as shown in Figure 12.

Open in a new tab
Users’ responses on whether it was clear to users that they were viewing a preprint, by audience type.On average, survey respondents indicated that preprints are very important, especially for the scientific community at large, and even more so for emerging topics like the SARS-CoV-2 virus and COVID-19 (see Figure 13).

Fifty-seven percent (95) of survey respondents reported that having preprints in PubMed and PMC did not impact their trust in these databases, but for those for whom it did, it was more likely to increase than decrease their trust (see Figure 14).

This example record includes green information panel identifying the record as a preprint that has not been peer reviewed, the preprint indicator in the citation metadata, and Cite tool pop-up window with the “[Preprint]” indicator.Additionally, the yellow information panel in PMC that displays prior to the abstract and includes related content links was expanded to include a pointer to the preprint on the source preprint server website and a link from the preprint record to an associated peer-reviewed journal version, when available (Figure 1).

Users may also access and view the preprint record directly from the source preprint server by clicking on the server link in this panel, the hyperlinked DOI in PMC and PubMed, or the server-branded “LinkOut” button in PubMed (Figure 2).
Preprints that were linked to published journal articles were labeled as “Updated” in PubMed (Figure 3).
In PMC, a “Published in” link was added to the search results display to take the user directly to the peer-reviewed journal version, if available (Figure 4).
This example includes the preprint indicator following the DOI as well as the Updated identifier, indicating that a peer-reviewed journal version is available.Figure 4.

The text in this panel notes that the article has not been peer reviewed and includes a link to more information about the “NIH Preprint Pilot.” To communicate the “NIH-supported” scope of the pilot, an NIH-branded preprint banner was also added to records in PMC (Figure 1).
A “Preprint” indicator was also added to the displayed citation metadata and “Cite” tool in PMC and PubMed to foster transparency as well as accurate citation (Figure 2).

Additionally, the yellow information panel in PMC that displays prior to the abstract and includes related content links was expanded to include a pointer to the preprint on the source preprint server website and a link from the preprint record to an associated peer-reviewed journal version, when available (Figure 1).

Users may also access and view the preprint record directly from the source preprint server by clicking on the server link in this panel, the hyperlinked DOI in PMC and PubMed, or the server-branded “LinkOut” button in PubMed (Figure 2).
Preprints that were linked to published journal articles were labeled as “Updated” in PubMed (Figure 3).
In PMC, a “Published in” link was added to the search results display to take the user directly to the peer-reviewed journal version, if available (Figure 4).
Of the preprint records added to PMC and PubMed, the majority were posted to either medRxiv (47%) or bioRxiv (38%) (Figure 5).
The volume of preprints identified as in scope for Phase 1 varied over time, peaking at 538 preprints in the first quarter of the pilot (June 9 – September 9, 2020; see Figure 6).
Since June 2020, there was quarterly growth in the number of NIH-supported authors selecting some type of Creative Commons license (see Figure 7).

Of the 2,767 preprint records available in PubMed at the end of October 2021, there were only 20 that were returned in search results that were not viewed.Accelerated discovery
Approximately 72% of or 2,512 preprints added to PMC and PubMed through June 2022 had been linked to a peer-reviewed journal version by December 2022 (Figure 9).
Survey respondents represented a cross-section of PMC and PubMed user groups, with one-third of respondents being researchers (Figure 10).

Sixty-two percent of survey respondents (201) reported having previously heard of preprints, although there was variability across user types (see also Figure 11):
Figure 11.

Survey responses indicated that users were generally able to distinguish that they were viewing a preprint record in PMC and PubMed; Seventy percent (177) indicated that it was “Clear,” noting differences across user types as shown in Figure 12.

Open in a new tab
Users’ responses on whether it was clear to users that they were viewing a preprint, by audience type.On average, survey respondents indicated that preprints are very important, especially for the scientific community at large, and even more so for emerging topics like the SARS-CoV-2 virus and COVID-19 (see Figure 13).

Fifty-seven percent (95) of survey respondents reported that having preprints in PubMed and PMC did not impact their trust in these databases, but for those for whom it did, it was more likely to increase than decrease their trust (see Figure 14).
Of the preprint records added to PMC and PubMed, the majority were posted to either medRxiv (47%) or bioRxiv (38%) (Figure 5).
The volume of preprints identified as in scope for Phase 1 varied over time, peaking at 538 preprints in the first quarter of the pilot (June 9 – September 9, 2020; see Figure 6).
Since June 2020, there was quarterly growth in the number of NIH-supported authors selecting some type of Creative Commons license (see Figure 7).
